verbose_text: Mutations in this MAF binding site, as well as in the adjacent type 2 diabetes associated SNP rs922691 showed a reduction in MAFA transactivation potential, demonstrating that MAFA contributes to the transcriptional regulation of CHRNB4 and suggests that loss of MAFA and/or MAFB in type 2 diabetic islets may result in compromised CHRNB4 expression and subsequently CHRN activity, thus contributing to the beta cell dysfunction observed.
